oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Soldier resting during a patrol near Vung Chua Mountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A soldier sitting in the grass and resting during a patrol. He is holding an M-16 rifle and has a set of keys attached to his uniform. His name appears to be "Metzger."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mountains; Military facilities; Bunkers; Forts & fortifications
United States. Army. Military Police Company, 194th; Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Qui Nhon (Vietnam)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Patrols were the most common assignment for the soldiers of the security detachment on Vung Chua. Patrols were detailed to check for Viet Cong activity and to set flares, mines, and seismic detectors.
